awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT:  Autonomous Battery Operating System (ABOS): An Adaptive and Comprehensive Approach to Efficient, Safe, and Secure Battery System Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Effective battery systems are a cornerstone of the next wave of
innovation. Emerging technologies including electric-drive vehicles
(EVs) and stationary energy storage systems require integrated
battery systems to provide sustained and reliable power. A unique
opportunity exists for the software-controlled battery management
system (BMS) to play a crucial role in enabling continued
innovation. However, there are several unaddressed challenges to
current BMS design. A battery's decreasing capacity over time due
to aging necessitates that BMS automatically adapt to battery
changes. Furthermore, future BMS systems will require autonomous
reasoning capabilities to make economically-sound decisions on
users' behalf (e.g., scheduling battery charging times in a
personalized fashion). This project injects intelligence
capabilities into BMS design with the development of the Autonomous
Battery Operating System (ABOS). ABOS enables more
energy-efficient, long-lasting, and secure battery-driven systems.
Furthermore, the PIs incorporate computational and cyber-security
aspects of ABOS design into their undergraduate- and graduate-level
courses.

ABOS advances the science of autonomous system design with
simultaneously introspective and extrospective learning. ABOS will
learn and adapt to user-initiated charging/discharging patterns,
reason about how these patterns affect the battery's
state-of-health, and respond to potential faults or attacks. The
PIs and their external collaborators will develop a hybrid EV
simulation environment to test the ability of ABOS to control a
physical battery system. The simulation environment will evaluate
the effectiveness of ABOS in predicting battery state, minimizing
cost of operation, and handling failures and threats.

por.por_cntn:
Effective battery systems are essential for emerging technologies in areas such as electric vehicles (EVs), consumer electronics, and energy storage systems. While advancements in battery hardware have driven progress, we are approaching the physical limits of current Lithium-ion technology. Additionally, safety concerns due to battery malfunctions are increasing. This highlights a unique opportunity for software-based autonomous systems to enhance battery-powered systems' safety and efficiency. Our project developed the Autonomous Battery Operating System (ABOS) to address these needs, aiming to: 

1) Enable autonomous reasoning about battery states.
2) Facilitate efficient decision-making for battery usage.
3) Learn and adapt to environmental impacts on battery efficiency.
4) Independently prevent and react to safety threats.

Intellectual Merit: The project combined embedded computer system design, power engineering, machine learning, and algorithm analysis to achieve:

  • Adaptive techniques for optimizing battery states, including workload offloading to edge servers and the development of an onboard microgrid creation for battery balancing.
  • Autonomous routing and charging algorithms for ABOS, with machine learning for traffic prediction and optimal EV-charging location recommendation in urban setting; near-optimal approximation algorithms were also developed to minimize charging costs and wait times for longer-distant trips.
  • Effective threat/fault detection and protection schemes, deploying hardware-assisted environments for security and software-based techniques for overcurrent detection.
  • Integration of components for battery state management, routing/charging, and security into ABOS. This involved building the 'Donkey' mobile robot platform with advanced power sensing and a custom hardware battery management system for intelligent charging.
  • Evaluation of ABOS on the Donkey platform demonstrated significant energy reduction through precise power-profiling and energy-aware path planning.

 These techniques and artifacts were shared through top-tier journal and conference publications.

 Broader Impacts:  The project engaged 18 Ph.D. students over six years, with ten completing their dissertations by the end of this project. Among the graduates, three have tenure-track positions at US institutions (William and Mary, University of Nevada-Las Vegas, and Kettering University), and three others have undertaken post-doctoral research in academia or industry (University of Michigan, IBM, and Southern University of Science and Technology). The rest have entered the industry, joining companies like GM and Freight Science. Moreover, the project's software artifacts, analyses, and results have been made publicly available for global research use (e.g., schematics for a custom BMS and an autonomous mobile platform are online).

The project also enriched the educational curriculum at Wayne State University. Concepts from this project have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses such as Cyber-Physical Systems, Real-Time and Embedded Operating Systems, Machine Learning, and Introduction to Mobility. Additionally, the project served as a model in recruitment presentations and mentoring economically-disadvantaged students in the Detroit area into computer science. The outcomes and results of this project were showcased in a mini-symposium at Wayne State University, where local industry representatives were invited to a poster and demo session for feedback and collaboration opportunities.
